utterances: Are you sad it's over?
You're going to give your crown away to someone else.
Oh, I'm not giving my crown, Rachel.
No, no, no, no, no. She gets her own crown.
The precious stays with me.
This year has been - I'm getting goosebumpy right now because all of the people that I've been able to meet, all of the lives that I think I've been able to touch.
This year has been - I'm excited.
I'm excited to meet my new sister-queen, whoever she is, and start this legacy.
Well, Denyse Gordon, the 2012 Ms. Veteran America.
She hands off her title to this year's winner at the pageant tonight in Leesburg, Virginia.
Denyse, thank you so much for talking with us.
Thank you very much.
My pleasure.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
There's an evil presence lurking in the cold waters off the Pacific Northwest; gelatinous six-inch long blobs of goo, maybe millions of them.
They're known as tunicates.
And no one is sure exactly where they came from, just that they want them gone.
Well, Janna Nichols is doing what she can.
She's been leading a motley crew of divers, armed with spatulas and old pieces of pipe, hoping to remove the pernicious blobs.
Janna Nichols joins us now from Vancouver, Washington, just a little north of Portland.
Hi, Janna.
Hey.
So describe these tunicates for someone who's never seen one.
What do they look like?
They can be anywhere from about an inch to maximum size of about six inches.
They are cylindrical shaped, clear, with two little siphons on the top.
So that seems - there are lots of weird sort of gooey things that live, you know, attached to rocks and old sunken ships down in the deep.
Why are these tunicates so hated?
What's so scary about them?
Well, the problem with tunicates - and there's actually three invasive ones that Washington is dealing with right now - is that they have no predators.
A species that comes from a different place that's transplanted here doesn't have anybody that eats them.
And so they take over underwater real estate, basically, and they crowd out the native species.
So you've actually been underwater with them.
What does it look like down there?
Is it just a - like a sea of these little guys waving in the water or what's it look like?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Pretty much.
The first time that I encountered these, by the time we got down to about 40 feet, which is roughly about where these start, it was pretty dark.
So it's kind of creepy.
And you've got your dive lights - this big flashlight thing that you're shining around - and soon we came across a clump of them.
So excited to see these.
And then we started kind of looking around with our dive lights and they were everywhere.
And we swam deeper, and deeper, and deeper, and they were covering the ocean floor, all over the place.
And they kind of were Star Trekkie because they kind of looked like they have a life of their own.
They kind shrunk down and moved around just a little bit.
Remember, they're attached at the base.
It's just kind of these big long cylinder things.
Sort of like those fur balls...
I was going to say...
...in ""Star Trek?
...it's like those Tribbles, for ""Star Trek,"" right.
Yeah.
They're all over.
So we don't know exactly where these come from.
But what's the best guess?
Couple of best guesses.
One is ballast water, that's a popular theory for invasive species.
Ships from overseas come, take on water in their homeports, and they come here.
And they're not supposed release the water in our waters.
Another theory is that they came from imported shellfish stock.
It's just unknown, and all we know is they're here and we got to deal with them.
And we're going to begin this hour on Capitol Hill, where House Republican leaders say they're ready to vote on a $50 billion package of spending cuts.
The cuts would hit programs including Medicaid, food stamps and student loans, among others, but at this hour, it's not clear whether Republicans have their votes together or not.
Things were shaken up today when the House rejected a major spending bill, the single-largest, non-military bill of the year, covering the departments of Education, Labor, Health and Human Services.
Now the sequence of events planned to settle the big budget and spending issue for the year seems to be in jeopardy.
Joining us for a quick update on the turmoil is NPR congressional reporter Andrea Seabrook.
Andrea, what's going on with the spending cuts bill?
Are moderate Republicans still vowing to vote against it?
Well, Michele, a substantial number of them still are going to vote against it, and that's, in part, why Republican leaders put the floor in recess right now.
There actually is nothing going on, on the floor of the House, while Republican leaders are counting up the votes they do have one more time.

You know, this is the third time leaders have announced they were going to bring this bill to the floor, and it's the third time people like me have sat here and watched the floor go into recess while the leaders frantically tallied up their votes again.
It seems those first two times leaders have acquiesced to moderates by taking things out of the bill.
Just this morning, Republican leaders rolled back some of their changes in the food stamp program and in eligibility for Medicaid to get more moderates to vote for it.

But they've also lowered the total amount of spending the bill would cut to under $50 billion; that's down about five billion from where it was a few weeks ago, and conservatives now on the other side have warned before that they won't vote for something that's under 50 billion.
So that could be part of the problem that leaders have today.
Andrea, you noted that House Republican leaders have been trying to get this done for weeks now.
Does this point to a leadership problem?
Absolutely, Michele.

Many blame--Republicans--their chronic problems now on the fact that powerful Texas Republican Tom DeLay is out of the leadership, though he still has a lot of clout in the party and works behind the scenes.

But with DeLay gone, this has been a real test for the abilities of Roy Blunt, who is trying to do DeLay's old job of majority leader while also continuing his own job as majority whip; that's the vote-counter.
Also, Speaker Dennis Hastert has had to try and hold together a party that is increasingly divided.
So the Republican leadership is definitely weakened right now.
And there are chairmen and rank-and-file members who, behind the scenes, would really like to take over some of those posts.
So they have little incentive to toe the party line right now.
Some of them would really like to see these spending cuts fail.
The House today also defeated what was supposed to be the final version of the annual spending bill that actually appropriates money for major social programs.
What happened to that?
Well, it's a similar situation to the spending cuts we were just talking about.
A bunch of moderates and a few other Republicans voted against the bill, many because it cut more than a billion dollars in health care, education and welfare programs.
The people who crafted the final bill also left out about $8 billion that was meant to go to prepare for an avian flu outbreak.

And what made it even harder for some to vote for it was the fact that the final bill dropped more than a billion dollars in earmarks for individual projects for specific members of the House and Senate.
At the same time, Democrats were 100 percent united against the bill.
And it appears that this vote just kind of snuck up on the leadership, and they lost it.
It also appears that Democratic unity is stronger even as Republican leadership seems to be weakened.
Absolutely.
It used to be that Republicans could count on pealing off a dozen or so conservative Democrats to vote for Republican bills, but Democrats have united and won these political fights.
And as they continue to win the fights, their resolve only stiffens.
NPR's Andrea Seabrook on the House side of the Capitol Building.
Thank you, Andrea.
You're welcome.
It's Thursday, the day we read from your e-mail.
And we've spent a good deal of time over the past weeks reporting on the riots in France.
The unrest has taken place in poor, largely immigrant communities in the suburbs of French cities.
Henry Eck of Atlanta sent this criticism of our work.
He writes, `You spoke of the despair which drives the violence.
That's a well-accepted but, in my opinion, incorrect explanation.
Even the young man in one of your stories, a law student from a poor neighborhood, didn't say that.
He said that his friends didn't have anything to do, and when they saw the violence, they joined in the fun.
Social injustice is evil, but it does not explain, nor excuse, criminal behavior.'
A couple of days ago I spoke with Reverend J.
Edwin Bacon, director of All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, California.
The IRS is investigating the church because of a sermon given there just days before the 2004 election.
The sermon criticized the war in Iraq, and the IRS says that may have violated the church's tax-exempt status.
Well, that interview brought in lots of mail.
This comment is from John Rinehart of Reading, Pennsylvania.
Mr. Rinehart says, `During 41 years in the ministry, I have frequently raised issues of public concern.
Sometimes biblical texts lead me to support the direction taken.
Other times the text leads to criticism.
However, supporting or criticizing an idea was not to be taken as endorsing or rejecting a candidate.
Mr. Rinehart continues, `Now I hear about what happened at All Saints in Pasadena.
I wonder if this nation is so divided that criticism is silenced; that the prophetic role of speaking truth to power is rejected as unpatriotic or investigated for breaking some law.
If so, my current anxiety may turn to fear.'
So what regions doe these naturally occur?
Is it over on the other side of the Pacific, or where is it at?
Yeah.
The ones, the particular ones that you and I are talking about today, came from, I believe, Asia area.
Thanks for having me.
Well, the point is that these are kids.
These are young people.
These are children.

There've already been 24 young people - Chicago public school students - who've been killed already this year in violent gun-related attacks because, in many cases, they were in the wrong place at the wrong time.
There's another hand of responsibility here and that is the parent.
Is asking the parent to keep an eye out on where your children are and be accountable to where your children are.
Yes, there are some tough kids out there.
There are some tough kids who are going to be incorrigible.
But many of the kids that are getting killed out there are innocent or getting caught in the wrong place at the wrong time because of gang violence.
Have you been able to talk to any parents about their perceptions?
I've heard from parents about this and see a number of parents interviewed about this.
And I think you'll get a mixed message here.
I think there's a lot of frustration - a lot of people are looking and don't know where to turn for answers.
So you'll see all of these is just another panacea that's not going to work.
But there's a lot of concern that we've got to do something because of this violence on the street, there's been - they're were marches, there have been protests.
And a lot of parents, I think, are willing to give it a chance.
So explain exactly how these financial penalties for parents work.
Well, the financial penalties are basically fines.
And here, you run into another problem.
This has been tried before.
Obviously, if it were that effective, we wouldn't have this continued violence.
But these fines are going to be issued against parents, who can accounts for their children.
There are exceptions.
If a child is on his way to or from work and, of course, if the child is in the company of an adult guardian or a parent, there won't be an issue.
But what we're talking about are young people who are out riding the buses in all hours of the day and night, who are in vulnerable places, and the parents are going to be asked to account for that.

There's one part of the new initiative that calls for patrol cars to go into high-crime areas on weekends and scan license plates of suspicious cars so, how do they determine what cars are suspicious?
Well, that's a big question and a lot of civil liberties advocates, I think, rightly so are questioning that.
There's been a lot of activity at the police department, cameras on the streets, increased activity in so-called high-crime areas.
That has been controversial.
The police department is saying that they're going to be checking against their records.
You know, obviously, they have a database that shows folks who are wanted, folks who have troubled backgrounds.
But there is a concern that this won't be used - that this tactic will be used indiscriminately.
I think the other question is that are police really have time to do that in these high-crime areas?
One of the reasons why violence is out of control is because in many cases the police are outnumbered and there are too many guns on the street.
So I think I'm pretty skeptical about whether or not that's an effective the policy.
